Why the "Morning Show" about sex scandal save only good actors
02 Nov 2019, 17:00 by Linda Zhuravleva
Critic Linda Zhuravleva believes that the new comedy drama Apple TV + raises important topics, but it catches the nostalgia with predictability.
On November 1, the Apple TV + streaming platform was launched immediately in one and a half hundred countries, including Russia. Among the platform‚Äôs projects was the comedy drama ‚ÄúMorning Show‚Äù.
The action takes place in the backstage of the fictitious television company UBA. Permanent host Alex Levy (Jennifer Aniston) arrives at work and finds out that her partner Mitch Kessler (Steve Carell) has just been fired for inappropriate behavior at work.



At the same time, the new head of the channel, Corey Ellison (Billy Crudup), believes that the dismissal of Kessler is a convenient occasion to shake up the program, which is in serious stagnation. Therefore, Alex decided to replace with a younger and more assertive presenter. The eccentric, but not indifferent and sincere journalist Bradley Jackson (Reese Witherspoon) is in the role of the latter.
Alex realizes that he is extremely vulnerable. The presenter can no longer significantly influence the new bosses, despite all her authority. And then in an attempt to defend her place under the sun, a woman decides to take a desperate step.



The Morning Show is not the first TV series show. The topic has already been raised in The Loudest Voice and News Room. But we must admit that the creators of the new series scrupulously approached their task. For example, CNN reporter and host Brian Stelter, author of Top of the Morning, acted as a consultant on the project.
The leading comedians of Hollywood were called to the main roles - Steve Carell, Jennifer Aniston and Reese Witherspoon. The latter has already revealed all the facets of its dramatic potential in the film ‚ÄúWild‚Äù by independent director Jean-Marc Vallee and his television series ‚ÄúBig Little Lies‚Äù. But nevertheless, the idea to bring together in one serious project the star faces of the iconic American comedies could not but intrigue the potential spectators of the new platform.
An ambiguous look at the #MeToo social movement
A few years ago, the discussion of the problem of sexual harassment first entered the global level. Actress Ashley Judd accused the famous Hollywood producer of inappropriate behavior. And the snowball, called the Weinstein effect, entailed numerous layoffs in large corporations.
The #MeToo movement was often accused of witch-hunting and violating the presumption of innocence. But one thing is clear: now even huge authority will not save a person who has compromised himself with obscene behavior from public condemnation. Sexual offenses are no longer forgiven to Hollywood figures.



The most difficult thing is when the universal favorite is at the center of the scandal, as was the case with Kevin Spacey. The character of the ‚ÄúMorning Show‚Äù Mitch Kessler is in exactly the same situation. The channel is in a hurry to exponentially repress a former colleague. And the ‚Äújudges‚Äù do not care if there has been abuse of power, tactless behavior or the usual affair at work.
The unexpected advantage of the series is that it tries to evaluate individual excesses in the fight against harassment.
Is it likely that relatively innocent people will fall under the rink? And will unjustly injured people like Mitch Kessler be ready to keep silent for the big goal of making the world safer for women? Or will they try to convey their point of view to the public?
Brilliant actors and lame dialogs
But the rest of the series is still difficult to call outstanding or at least devoid of secondaryity and clich√©. There is a feeling that wonderful actors are cramped within too deliberate and unnatural cues, sometimes sounding like clumsy political agitation.
Take at least the moment when one of the heroines in a bright red dress makes a hot speech, sitting among men in black. It can be seen that the creators tried to present the scene unusually. But this is all done quite rudely and in the forehead. And the pathos and pretentiousness that accompany the monologue do not allow us to believe that it sounds from the mouth of a living person.



Obviously, Apple is ready to spend fabulous money on its own serial content. Jennifer Aniston and Reese Witherspoon receive * $ 2 million per episode. In total, two seasons cost $ 300 million *. * Source: Jennifer Aniston and Reese Witherspoon‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Morning Show‚Äô Salaries Are Mind ‚Äë Bogglingly Huge * Source: Inside Apple‚Äôs Long, Bumpy Road to Hollywood
These figures suggest that the company is completely not interested in the failure of its projects. On the contrary, Apple takes serial production seriously. But to say whether a truly complete work will come out of the Morning Show will be possible only in the finale of the first season.
